098/**
099 * Class illustrating use of {@link SQLXML} to operate on XML data.
100 *<p>
101 * This class also serves as the mapping class for a composite type
102 * {@code javatest.onexml}, the better to verify that {@link SQLData}
103 * input/output works too. That's why it has to implement SQLData.
104 *<p>
105 * Everything mentioning the type XML here needs a conditional implementor tag
106 * in case of being loaded into a PostgreSQL instance built without that type.
107 */
108@SQLAction(provides="postgresql_xml", install=
109    "SELECT CASE (SELECT 1 FROM pg_type WHERE typname = 'xml') WHEN 1" +
110    " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_xml,' || " +
111    " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
112    "END"
113)
114
115@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_ge_80400",
116    provides="postgresql_xml_ge84",
117    install=
118    "SELECT CASE (SELECT 1 FROM pg_type WHERE typname = 'xml') WHEN 1" +
119    " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_xml_ge84,' || " +
120    " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
121    "END"
122)
123
124@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="echoXMLParameter",
125    install=
126    "WITH" +
127    " s(how) AS (SELECT generate_series(1, 7))," +
128    " t(x) AS (" +
129    "  SELECT table_to_xml('pg_catalog.pg_operator', true, false, '')" +
130    " )," +
131    " r(howin, howout, isdoc) AS (" +
132    "  SELECT" +
133    "   i.how, o.how," +
134    "   javatest.echoxmlparameter(x, i.how, o.how) IS DOCUMENT" +
135    "  FROM" +
136    "   t, s AS i, s AS o" +
137    "  WHERE" +
138    "   NOT (i.how = 6 and o.how = 7)" + // 6->7 unreliable in some JREs
139    " ) " +
140    "SELECT" +
141    " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
142    "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'SQLXML echos succeeded')" +
143    "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'SQLXML echos had problems')" +
144    " END " +
145    "FROM" +
146    " r"
147)
148
149@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="proxiedXMLEcho",
150    install=
151    "WITH" +
152    " s(how) AS (SELECT unnest('{1,2,4,5,6,7}'::int[]))," +
153    " t(x) AS (" +
154    "  SELECT table_to_xml('pg_catalog.pg_operator', true, false, '')" +
155    " )," +
156    " r(how, isdoc) AS (" +
157    "  SELECT" +
158    "   how," +
159    "   javatest.proxiedxmlecho(x, how) IS DOCUMENT" +
160    "  FROM" +
161    "   t, s" +
162    " )" +
163    "SELECT" +
164    " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
165    "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'proxied SQLXML echos succeeded')" +
166    "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING'," +
167    "       'proxied SQLXML echos had problems')" +
168    " END " +
169    "FROM" +
170    " r"
171)
172
173@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="lowLevelXMLEcho",
174    install={
175    "SELECT" +
176    " preparexmlschema('schematest', $$" +
177    "<xs:schema" +
178    " xmlns:xs='http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema'" +
179    " targetNamespace='urn:testme'" +
180    " elementFormDefault='qualified'>" +
181    " <xs:element name='row'>" +
182    "  <xs:complexType>" +
183    "   <xs:sequence>" +
184    "    <xs:element name='textcol' type='xs:string' nillable='true'/>" +
185    "    <xs:element name='intcol' type='xs:integer' nillable='true'/>" +
186    "   </xs:sequence>" +
187    "  </xs:complexType>" +
188    " </xs:element>" +
189    "</xs:schema>" +
190    "$$, 'http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema', 5)",
191
192    "WITH" +
193    " s(how) AS (SELECT unnest('{4,5,7}'::int[]))," +
194    " r(isdoc) AS (" +
195    " SELECT" +
196    "  javatest.lowlevelxmlecho(" +
197    "   query_to_xml(" +
198    "    'SELECT ''hi'' AS textcol, 1 AS intcol', true, true, 'urn:testme'"+
199    "   ), how, params) IS DOCUMENT" +
200    " FROM" +
201    "  s," +
202    "  (SELECT 'schematest' AS schema) AS params" +
203    " )" +
204    "SELECT" +
205    " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
206    "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XML Schema tests succeeded')" +
207    "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING'," +
208    "       'XML Schema tests had problems')" +
209    " END " +
210    "FROM" +
211    " r"
212    }
213)

215@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml",
216           requires={"prepareXMLTransform", "transformXML"},
217    install={
218        "REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTION javatest.prepareXMLTransformWithJava" +
219        " (pg_catalog.varchar, pg_catalog.xml, integer, boolean, boolean," +
220        "  pg_catalog.RECORD)" +
221        " FROM PUBLIC",
222
223        "SELECT" +
224        " javatest.prepareXMLTransform('distinctElementNames'," +
225        "'<xsl:transform version=''1.0''" +
226        " xmlns:xsl=''http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform''" +
227        " xmlns:exsl=''http://exslt.org/common''" +
228        " xmlns:set=''http://exslt.org/sets''" +
229        " extension-element-prefixes=''exsl set''" +
230        ">" +
231        " <xsl:output method=''xml'' indent=''no''/>" +
232        " <xsl:template match=''/''>" +
233        "  <xsl:variable name=''enames''>" +
234        "   <xsl:for-each select=''//*''>" +
235        "    <ename><xsl:value-of select=''local-name()''/></ename>" +
236        "   </xsl:for-each>" +
237        "  </xsl:variable>" +
238        "  <xsl:for-each" +
239        "   select=''set:distinct(exsl:node-set($enames)/ename)''>" +
240        "   <xsl:sort select=''string()''/>" +
241        "   <den><xsl:value-of select=''.''/></den>" +
242        "  </xsl:for-each>" +
243        " </xsl:template>" +
244        "</xsl:transform>', how => 5, enableExtensionFunctions => true)",
245
246        "SELECT" +
247        " javatest.prepareXMLTransformWithJava('getPLJavaVersion'," +
248        "'<xsl:transform version=''1.0''" +
249        " xmlns:xsl=''http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform''" +
250        " xmlns:java=''http://xml.apache.org/xalan/java''" +
251        " exclude-result-prefixes=''java''" +
252        ">" +
253        " <xsl:template match=''/''>" +
254        "  <xsl:value-of" +
255        "   select=''java:java.lang.System.getProperty(" +
256        "    \"org.postgresql.pljava.version\")''" +
257        "  />" +
258        " </xsl:template>" +
259        "</xsl:transform>', enableExtensionFunctions => true)",
260
261        "SELECT" +
262        " CASE WHEN" +
263        "  javatest.transformXML('distinctElementNames'," +
264        "   '<a><c/><e/><b/><b/><d/></a>', 5, 5)::text" +
265        "  =" +
266        "   '<den>a</den><den>b</den><den>c</den><den>d</den><den>e</den>'"+
267        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XSLT 1.0 test succeeded')" +
268        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'XSLT 1.0 test failed')" +
269        " END",
270
271        "SELECT" +
272        " CASE WHEN" +
273        "  javatest.transformXML('getPLJavaVersion', '')::text" +
274        "  OPERATOR(pg_catalog.=) extversion" +
275        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XSLT 1.0 with Java succeeded')" +
276        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'XSLT 1.0 with Java failed')" +
277        " END" +
278        " FROM pg_catalog.pg_extension" +
279        " WHERE extname = 'pljava'"
280    }
281)
282@MappedUDT(schema="javatest", name="onexml", structure="c1 xml",
283           implementor="postgresql_xml",
284           comment="A composite type mapped by the PassXML example class")
285public class PassXML implements SQLData
286{
287    static SQLXML s_sx;
288
289    static TransformerFactory s_tf = TransformerFactory.newDefaultInstance();
290
291    static Map<String,Templates> s_tpls = new HashMap<>();
292
293    static Map<String,Schema> s_schemas = new HashMap<>();
294
295    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
296    public static String inXMLoutString(SQLXML in) throws SQLException
297    {
298        return in.getString();
299    }
300
301    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
302    public static SQLXML inStringoutXML(String in) throws SQLException
303    {
304        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
305        SQLXML result = c.createSQLXML();
306        result.setString(in);
307        return result;
308    }
309
310    /**
311     * Echo an XML parameter back, exercising seven different ways
312     * (howin =&gt; 1-7) of reading an SQLXML object, and seven
313     * (howout =&gt; 1-7) of returning one.
314     *<p>
315     * If howin =&gt; 0, the XML parameter is simply saved in a static. It can
316     * be read in a subsequent call with sx =&gt; null, but only in the same
317     * transaction.
318     *<p>
319     * The "echoing" is done (in the {@code echoXML} method below) using a
320     * {@code Transformer}, that is, the "TrAX" Transformation API for XML
321     * supplied in Java. It illustrates how an identity {@code Transformer} can
322     * be used to get the XML content from the source to the result for any of
323     * the APIs selectable by howin and howout.
324     *<p>
325     * It also illustrates something else. When using StAX (6 for howin
326     * or howout) and XML of the {@code CONTENT} flavor (multiple top-level
327     * elements, characters outside the top element, etc.), it is easy to
328     * construct examples that fail. The fault is not really with the StAX API,
329     * nor with TrAX proper, but with the small handful of bridge classes that
330     * were added to the JRE with StAX's first appearance, to make it
331     * interoperate with TrAX. It is not that those classes completely overlook
332     * the {@code CONTENT} case: they make some efforts to handle it. Just not
333     * the right ones, and given the Java developers' usual reluctance to change
334     * such longstanding behavior, that's probably not getting fixed.
335     *<p>
336     * Moral: StAX is a nice API, have no fear to use it directly in
337     * freshly-developed code, but: when using TrAX, make every effort to supply
338     * a {@code Transformer} with {@code Source} and {@code Result} objects of
339     * <em>any</em> kind other than StAX.
340     */
341    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
342              provides="echoXMLParameter")
343    public static SQLXML echoXMLParameter(SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
344    throws SQLException
345    {
346        if ( null == sx )
347            sx = s_sx;
348        if ( 0 == howin )
349        {
350            s_sx = sx;
351            return null;
352        }
353        return echoSQLXML(sx, howin, howout);
354    }
355
356    /**
357     * Echo an XML parameter back, but with parameter and return types of
358     * PostgreSQL {@code text}.
359     *<p>
360     * The other version of this method needs a conditional implementor tag
361     * because it cannot be declared in a PostgreSQL instance that was built
362     * without {@code libxml} support and the PostgreSQL {@code XML} type.
363     * But this version can, simply by mapping the {@code SQLXML} parameter
364     * and return types to the SQL {@code text} type. The Java code is no
365     * different.
366     *<p>
367     * Note that it's possible for both declarations to coexist in PostgreSQL
368     * (because as far as it is concerned, their signatures are different), but
369     * these two Java methods cannot have the same name (because they differ
370     * only in annotations, not in the declared Java types). So, this one needs
371     * a slightly tweaked name, and a {@code name} attribute in the annotation
372     * so PostgreSQL sees the right name.
373     */
374    @Function(schema="javatest", name="echoXMLParameter", type="text")
375    public static SQLXML echoXMLParameter_(
376        @SQLType("text") SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
377    throws SQLException
378    {
379        return echoXMLParameter(sx, howin, howout);
380    }
381
382    /**
383     * "Echo" an XML parameter not by creating a new writable {@code SQLXML}
384     * object at all, but simply returning the passed-in readable one untouched.
385     */
386    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
387    public static SQLXML bounceXMLParameter(SQLXML sx) throws SQLException
388    {
389        return sx;
390    }
391
392    /**
393     * Just like {@link bounceXMLParameter} but with parameter and return typed
394     * as {@code text}, and so usable on a PostgreSQL instance lacking the XML
395     * type.
396     */
397    @Function(schema="javatest", type="text", name="bounceXMLParameter")
398    public static SQLXML bounceXMLParameter_(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx)
399    throws SQLException
400    {
401        return sx;
402    }
403
404    /**
405     * Just like {@link bounceXMLParameter} but with the parameter typed as
406     * {@code text} and the return type left as XML, so functions as a cast.
407     *<p>
408     * Slower than the other cases, because it must verify that the input really
409     * is XML before blindly calling it a PostgreSQL XML type. But the speed
410     * compares respectably to PostgreSQL's own CAST(text AS xml), at least for
411     * larger values; I am seeing Java pull ahead right around 32kB of XML data
412     * and beat PG by a factor of 2 or better at sizes of 1 or 2 MB.
413     * Unsurprisingly, PG has the clear advantage when values are very short.
414     */
415    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
416    public static SQLXML castTextXML(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx)
417    throws SQLException
418    {
419        return sx;
420    }
421
422    /**
423     * Precompile an XSL transform {@code source} and save it (for the
424     * current session) as {@code name}.
425     *<p>
426     * Each value of {@code how}, 1-7, selects a different way of presenting
427     * the {@code SQLXML} object to the XSL processor.
428     *<p>
429     * Passing {@code true} for {@code enableExtensionFunctions} allows the
430     * transform to use extensions that the Java XSLT implementation supports,
431     * such as functions from EXSLT. Those are disabled by default.
432     *<p>
433     * Passing {@code false} for {@code builtin} will allow a
434     * {@code TransformerFactory} other than Java's built-in one to be found
435     * using the usual search order and the context class loader (normally
436     * the PL/Java class path for the schema where this function is declared).
437     * The default of {@code true} ensures that the built-in Java XSLT 1.0
438     * implementation is used. A transformer implementation other than Xalan
439     * may not recognize the feature controlled by
440     * {@code enableExtensionFunctions}, so failure to configure that feature
441     * will be logged as a warning if {@code builtin} is {@code false}, instead
442     * of thrown as an exception.
443     *<p>
444     * Out of the box, Java's transformers only support XSLT 1.0. See the S9
445     * example for more capabilities (at the cost of downloading the Saxon jar).
446     */
447    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
448              provides="prepareXMLTransform")
449    public static void prepareXMLTransform(String name, SQLXML source,
450        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int how,
451        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean enableExtensionFunctions,
452        @SQLType(defaultValue="true") boolean builtin,
453        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
454    throws SQLException
455    {
456        prepareXMLTransform(
457            name, source, how, enableExtensionFunctions, adjust, builtin,
458            /* withJava */ false);
459    }
460
461    /**
462     * Precompile an XSL transform {@code source} and save it (for the
463     * current session) as {@code name}, where the transform may call Java
464     * methods.
465     *<p>
466     * Otherwise identical to {@code prepareXMLTransform}, this version sets the
467     * {@code TransformerFactory}'s {@code extensionClassLoader} (to the context
468     * class loader, normally the PL/Java class path for the schema where this
469     * function is declared), so the transform will be able to use
470     * xalan's Java call syntax to call any public Java methods that would be
471     * accessible to this class. (That can make a big difference in usefulness
472     * for the otherwise rather limited XSLT 1.0.)
473     *<p>
474     * As with {@code enableExtensionFunctions}, failure by the transformer
475     * implementation to recognize or allow the {@code extensionClassLoader}
476     * property will be logged as a warning if {@code builtin} is {@code false},
477     * rather than thrown as an exception.
478     *<p>
479     * This example function will be installed with {@code EXECUTE} permission
480     * revoked from {@code PUBLIC}, as it essentially confers the ability to
481     * create arbitrary new Java functions, so should only be granted to roles
482     * you would be willing to grant {@code USAGE ON LANGUAGE java}.
483     *<p>
484     * Because this function only prepares the transform, and
485     * {@link #transformXML transformXML} applies it, there is some division of
486     * labor in determining what limits apply to its behavior. The use of this
487     * method instead of {@code prepareXMLTransform} determines whether the
488     * transform is allowed to see external Java methods at all; it will be
489     * the policy permissions granted to {@code transformXML} that control what
490     * those methods can do when the transform is applied. For now, that method
491     * is defined in the trusted/sandboxed {@code java} language, so this
492     * function could reasonably be granted to any role with {@code USAGE} on
493     * {@code java}. If, by contrast, {@code transformXML} were declared in the
494     * 'untrusted' {@code javaU}, it would be prudent to allow only superusers
495     * access to this function, just as only they can {@code CREATE FUNCTION} in
496     * an untrusted language.
497     */
498    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
499              provides="prepareXMLTransform")
500    public static void prepareXMLTransformWithJava(String name, SQLXML source,
501        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int how,
502        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean enableExtensionFunctions,
503        @SQLType(defaultValue="true") boolean builtin,
504        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
505    throws SQLException
506    {
507        prepareXMLTransform(
508            name, source, how, enableExtensionFunctions, adjust, builtin,
509            /* withJava */ true);
510    }
511
512    private static void prepareXMLTransform(String name, SQLXML source, int how,
513        boolean enableExtensionFunctions, ResultSet adjust, boolean builtin,
514        boolean withJava)
515    throws SQLException
516    {
517        TransformerFactory tf =
518            builtin
519            ? TransformerFactory.newDefaultInstance()
520            : TransformerFactory.newInstance();
521        String exf =
522          "http://www.oracle.com/xml/jaxp/properties/enableExtensionFunctions";
523        String ecl = "jdk.xml.transform.extensionClassLoader";
524        Source src = sxToSource(source, how, adjust);
525        try
526        {
527            try
528            {
529                tf.setFeature(exf, enableExtensionFunctions);
530            }
531            catch ( TransformerConfigurationException e )
532            {
533                logMessage("WARNING",
534                    "non-builtin transformer: ignoring " + e.getMessage());
535            }
536
537            if ( withJava )
538            {
539                try
540                {
541                    tf.setAttribute(ecl,
542                        Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader());
543                }
544                catch ( IllegalArgumentException e )
545                {
546                    logMessage("WARNING",
547                    "non-builtin transformer: ignoring " + e.getMessage());
548                }
549            }
550
551            s_tpls.put(name, tf.newTemplates(src));
552        }
553        catch ( TransformerException te )
554        {
555            throw new SQLException(
556                "Preparing XML transformation: " + te.getMessage(), te);
557        }
558    }
559
560    /**
561     * Transform some XML according to a named transform prepared with
562     * {@code prepareXMLTransform}.
563     *<p>
564     * Pass null for {@code transformName} to get a plain identity transform
565     * (not such an interesting thing to do, unless you also specify indenting).
566     */
567    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
568              provides="transformXML")
569    public static SQLXML transformXML(
570        String transformName, SQLXML source,
571        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int howin,
572        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int howout,
573        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust,
574        @SQLType(optional=true) Boolean indent,
575        @SQLType(optional=true) Integer indentWidth)
576    throws SQLException
577    {
578        Templates tpl = null == transformName? null: s_tpls.get(transformName);
579        Source src = sxToSource(source, howin, adjust);
580
581        if ( Boolean.TRUE.equals(indent)  &&  0 == howout )
582            howout = 4; // transformer only indents if writing a StreamResult
583
584        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
585        SQLXML result = c.createSQLXML();
586        Result rlt = sxToResult(result, howout, adjust);
587
588        try
589        {
590            Transformer t =
591                null == tpl ? s_tf.newTransformer() : tpl.newTransformer();
592            /*
593             * For the non-SAX/StAX/DOM flavors of output, you're responsible
594             * for setting the Transformer to use the server encoding.
595             */
596            if ( rlt instanceof StreamResult )
597                t.setOutputProperty(ENCODING,
598                    System.getProperty("org.postgresql.server.encoding"));
599            else if ( Boolean.TRUE.equals(indent) )
600                logMessage("WARNING",
601                    "indent requested, but howout specifies a non-stream " +
602                    "Result type; no indenting will happen");
603
604            if ( null != indent )
605                t.setOutputProperty("indent", indent ? "yes" : "no");
606            if ( null != indentWidth )
607                t.setOutputProperty(
608                    "{http://xml.apache.org/xalan}indent-amount",
609                    "" + indentWidth);
610
611            t.transform(src, rlt);
612        }
613        catch ( TransformerException te )
614        {
615            throw new SQLException("Transforming XML: " + te.getMessage(), te);
616        }
617
618        return ensureClosed(rlt, result, howout);
619    }
620
621    /**
622     * Precompile a schema {@code source} in schema language {@code lang}
623     * and save it (for the current session) as {@code name}.
624     *<p>
625     * Each value of {@code how}, 1-7, selects a different way of presenting
626     * the {@code SQLXML} object to the schema parser.
627     *<p>
628     * The {@code lang} parameter is a URI that identifies a known schema
629     * language. The only language a Java runtime is required to support is
630     * W3C XML Schema 1.0, with URI {@code http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}.
631     */
632    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
633    public static void prepareXMLSchema(
634        String name, SQLXML source, String lang, int how)
635    throws SQLException
636    {
637        try
638        {
639            s_schemas.put(name,
640                SchemaFactory.newInstance(lang)
641                .newSchema(sxToSource(source, how)));
642        }
643        catch ( SAXException e )
644        {
645            throw new SQLException(
646                "failed to prepare schema: " + e.getMessage(), e);
647        }
648    }
649
650    private static SQLXML echoSQLXML(SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
651    throws SQLException
652    {
653        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
654        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
655        Source src = sxToSource(sx, howin);
656        Result rlt = sxToResult(rx, howout);
657
658        try
659        {
660            Transformer t = s_tf.newTransformer();
661            /*
662             * For the non-SAX/StAX/DOM flavors of output, you're responsible
663             * for setting the Transformer to use the server encoding.
664             */
665            if ( howout < 5 )
666                t.setOutputProperty(ENCODING,
667                    System.getProperty("org.postgresql.server.encoding"));
668            t.transform(src, rlt);
669        }
670        catch ( TransformerException te )
671        {
672            throw new SQLException("XML transformation failed", te);
673        }
674
675        return ensureClosed(rlt, rx, howout);
676    }
677
678    /**
679     * Echo the XML parameter back, using lower-level manipulations than
680     * {@code echoXMLParameter}.
681     *<p>
682     * This illustrates how the simple use of {@code t.transform(src,rlt)}
683     * in {@code echoSQLXML} substitutes for a lot of fiddly case-by-case code,
684     * but when coding for a specific case, all the generality of {@code
685     * transform} may not be needed. It can be interesting to compare memory use
686     * when XML values are large.
687     *<p>
688     * This method has been revised to demonstrate, even for low-level
689     * manipulations, how much fiddliness can now be avoided through use of the
690     * {@link Adjusting.XML.SourceResult} class, and how to make adjustments to
691     * parsing restrictions by passing the optional row-typed parameter
692     * <em>adjust</em>, which defaults to an empty row. For example, passing
693     *<pre>
694     * adjust =&gt; (select a from
695     *            (true as allowdtd, true as expandentityreferences) as a)
696     *</pre>
697     * would allow a document that contains an internal DTD subset and uses
698     * entities defined there.
699     *<p>
700     * The older, pre-{@code SourceResult} code for doing low-level XML echo
701     * has been moved to the {@code oldSchoolLowLevelEcho} method below. It can
702     * still be exercised by calling this method, explicitly passing
703     * {@code adjust => NULL}.
704     */
705    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84",
706        provides="lowLevelXMLEcho")
707    public static SQLXML lowLevelXMLEcho(
708        SQLXML sx, int how, @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
709    throws SQLException
710    {
711        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
712        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
713
714        if ( null == adjust )
715            return oldSchoolLowLevelEcho(rx, sx, how);
716
717        Adjusting.XML.SourceResult axsr =
718            rx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.SourceResult.class);
719
720        switch ( how )
721        {
722        /*
723         * The first four cases all present the content as unparsed bytes or
724         * characters, so there is nothing to adjust on the source side.
725         */
726        case 1:
727            axsr.set(new StreamSource(sx.getBinaryStream()));
728            break;
729        case 2:
730            axsr.set(new StreamSource(sx.getCharacterStream()));
731            break;
732        case 3:
733            axsr.set(sx.getString());
734            break;
735        case 4:
736            axsr.set(sx.getSource(StreamSource.class));
737            break;
738        /*
739         * The remaining cases present the content in parsed form, and therefore
740         * may involve parsers that can be adjusted according to the supplied
741         * preferences.
742         */
743        case 5:
744            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
745                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.SAXSource.class)));
746            break;
747        case 6:
748            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
749                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.StAXSource.class)));
750            break;
751        case 7:
752            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
753                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.DOMSource.class)));
754            break;
755        default:
756            throw new SQLDataException(
757                "how must be 1-7 for lowLevelXMLEcho", "22003");
758        }
759
760        /*
761         * Adjustments can also be applied to the SourceResult itself, where
762         * they will affect any implicitly-created parser used to verify or
763         * re-encode the content, if it was supplied in unparsed form.
764         */
765        return applyAdjustments(adjust, axsr).get().getSQLXML();
766    }
767
768    /**
769     * Apply adjustments (supplied as a row type with a named column for each
770     * desired adjustment and its value) to an instance of
771     * {@link Adjusting.XML.Parsing}.
772     *<p>
773     * Column names in the <em>adjust</em> row are case-insensitive versions of
774     * the method names in {@link Adjusting.XML.Parsing}, and the value of each
775     * column should be of the appropriate type (at present, boolean for all of
776     * them).
777     * @param adjust A row type as described above, possibly of no columns if no
778     * adjustments are wanted
779     * @param axp An instance of Adjusting.XML.Parsing
780     * @return axp, after applying any adjustments
781     */
782    public static <T extends Adjusting.XML.Parsing<? super T>>
783    T applyAdjustments(ResultSet adjust, T axp)
784    throws SQLException
785    {
786        ResultSetMetaData rsmd = adjust.getMetaData();
787        int n = rsmd.getColumnCount();
788
789        for ( int i = 1; i <= n; ++i )
790        {
791            String k = rsmd.getColumnLabel(i);
792            if ( "allowDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
793                axp.allowDTD(adjust.getBoolean(i));
794            else if ( "externalGeneralEntities".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
795                axp.externalGeneralEntities(adjust.getBoolean(i));
796            else if ( "externalParameterEntities".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
797                axp.externalParameterEntities(adjust.getBoolean(i));
798            else if ( "loadExternalDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
799                axp.loadExternalDTD(adjust.getBoolean(i));
800            else if ( "xIncludeAware".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
801                axp.xIncludeAware(adjust.getBoolean(i));
802            else if ( "expandEntityReferences".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
803                axp.expandEntityReferences(adjust.getBoolean(i));
804            else if ( "elementAttributeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
805                axp.elementAttributeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
806            else if ( "entityExpansionLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
807                axp.entityExpansionLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
808            else if ( "entityReplacementLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
809                axp.entityReplacementLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
810            else if ( "maxElementDepth".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
811                axp.maxElementDepth(adjust.getInt(i));
812            else if ( "maxGeneralEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
813                axp.maxGeneralEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
814            else if ( "maxParameterEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
815                axp.maxParameterEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
816            else if ( "maxXMLNameLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
817                axp.maxXMLNameLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
818            else if ( "totalEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
819                axp.totalEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
820            else if ( "accessExternalDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
821                axp.accessExternalDTD(adjust.getString(i));
822            else if ( "accessExternalSchema".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
823                axp.accessExternalSchema(adjust.getString(i));
824            else if ( "schema".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
825            {
826                try
827                {
828                    axp.schema(s_schemas.get(adjust.getString(i)));
829                }
830                catch (UnsupportedOperationException e)
831                {
832                }
833            }
834            else
835                throw new SQLDataException(
836                    "unrecognized name \"" + k + "\" for parser adjustment",
837                    "22000");
838        }
839        return axp;
840    }
841
842    /**
843     * An obsolescent example, showing what was required to copy from one
844     * {@code SQLXML} object to another, using the various supported APIs,
845     * without using {@link Adjusting.XML.SourceResult}, or at least without
846     * using it much. It is still used in case 4 to be sure of getting a
847     * {@code StreamResult} that matches the byte-or-character-ness of the
848     * {@code StreamSource}. How to handle that case without
849     * {@code SourceResult} is left as an exercise.
850     */
851    private static SQLXML oldSchoolLowLevelEcho(SQLXML rx, SQLXML sx, int how)
852    throws SQLException
853    {
854        try
855        {
856            switch ( how )
857            {
858            case 1:
859                InputStream is = sx.getBinaryStream();
860                OutputStream os = rx.setBinaryStream();
861                shovelBytes(is, os);
862                break;
863            case 2:
864                Reader r = sx.getCharacterStream();
865                Writer w = rx.setCharacterStream();
866                shovelChars(r, w);
867                break;
868            case 3:
869                rx.setString(sx.getString());
870                break;
871            case 4:
872                StreamSource ss = sx.getSource(StreamSource.class);
873                Adjusting.XML.StreamResult sr =
874                    rx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.StreamResult.class);
875                is = ss.getInputStream();
876                r  = ss.getReader();
877                if ( null != is )
878                {
879                    os = sr.preferBinaryStream().get().getOutputStream();
880                    shovelBytes(is, os);
881                    break;
882                }
883                if ( null != r )
884                {
885                    w  = sr.preferCharacterStream().get().getWriter();
886                    shovelChars(r, w);
887                    break;
888                }
889                throw new SQLDataException(
890                    "StreamSource contained neither InputStream nor Reader");
891            case 5:
892                SAXSource sxs = sx.getSource(SAXSource.class);
893                SAXResult sxr = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
894                XMLReader xr  = sxs.getXMLReader();
895                if ( null == xr )
896                {
897                    SAXParserFactory spf = SAXParserFactory.newInstance();
898                    spf.setNamespaceAware(true);
899                    xr = spf.newSAXParser().getXMLReader();
900                    /*
901                     * Important: before copying this example code for another
902                     * use, consider whether the input XML might be untrusted.
903                     * If so, the new XMLReader created here should have several
904                     * features given safe default settings as outlined in the
905                     * OWASP guidelines. (This branch is not reached when sx is
906                     * a PL/Java native SQLXML instance, as xr will be non-null
907                     * and already configured.)
908                     */
909                }
910                ContentHandler ch = sxr.getHandler();
911                xr.setContentHandler(ch);
912                if ( ch instanceof DTDHandler )
913                    xr.setDTDHandler((DTDHandler)ch);
914                LexicalHandler lh = sxr.getLexicalHandler();
915                if ( null == lh  &&  ch instanceof LexicalHandler )
916                lh = (LexicalHandler)ch;
917                if ( null != lh )
918                    xr.setProperty(
919                        "http://xml.org/sax/properties/lexical-handler", lh);
920                xr.parse(sxs.getInputSource());
921                break;
922            case 6:
923                StAXSource sts = sx.getSource(StAXSource.class);
924                StAXResult str = rx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
925                XMLOutputFactory xof = XMLOutputFactory.newInstance();
926                /*
927                 * The Source has either an event reader or a stream reader. Use
928                 * the event reader directly, or create one around the stream
929                 * reader.
930                 */
931                XMLEventReader xer = sts.getXMLEventReader();
932                if ( null == xer )
933                {
934                    XMLInputFactory  xif = XMLInputFactory .newInstance();
935                    xif.setProperty(xif.IS_NAMESPACE_AWARE, true);
936                    /*
937                     * Important: before copying this example code for another
938                     * use, consider whether the input XML might be untrusted.
939                     * If so, the new XMLInputFactory created here might want
940                     * several properties given safe default settings as
941                     * outlined in the OWASP guidelines. (When sx is a PL/Java
942                     * native SQLXML instance, the XMLStreamReader obtained
943                     * below will already have been so configured.)
944                     */
945                    xer = xif.createXMLEventReader(sts.getXMLStreamReader());
946                }
947                /*
948                 * Were you thinking the above could be simply
949                 * createXMLEventReader(sts) by analogy with the writer below?
950                 * Good thought, but the XMLInputFactory implementation that's
951                 * included in OpenJDK doesn't implement the case where the
952                 * Source argument is a StAXSource! Two lines would do it.
953                 */
954                /*
955                 * Because of a regression in Java 9 and later, the line below,
956                 * while working in Java 8 and earlier, will produce a
957                 * ClassCastException in Java 9 through (for sure) 12, (almost
958                 * certainly) 13, and on until some future version fixes the
959                 * regression, if ever, if 'str' wraps any XMLStreamWriter
960                 * implementation other than the inaccessible one from the guts
961                 * of the JDK itself. The bug has been reported but (as of this
962                 * writing) is still in the maddening limbo phase of the Java
963                 * bug reporting cycle, where no bug number can refer to it. See
964                 * lowLevelXMLEcho() above for code to do this copy successfully
965                 * using an Adjusting.XML.SourceResult.
966                 */
967                XMLEventWriter xew = xof.createXMLEventWriter(str);
968                xew.add(xer);
969                xew.close();
970                xer.close();
971                break;
972            case 7:
973                DOMSource ds = sx.getSource(DOMSource.class);
974                DOMResult dr = rx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
975                dr.setNode(ds.getNode());
976                break;
977            default:
978                throw new SQLDataException(
979                    "how must be 1-7 for lowLevelXMLEcho", "22003");
980            }
981        }
982        catch ( IOException e )
983        {
984            throw new SQLException(
985                "IOException in lowLevelXMLEcho", "58030", e);
986        }
987        catch (
988            ParserConfigurationException | SAXException | XMLStreamException e )
989        {
990            throw new SQLException(
991                "XML exception in lowLevelXMLEcho", "22000", e);
992        }
993        return rx;
994    }
995
996    /**
997     * Proxy a PL/Java SQLXML source object as if it were of a non-PL/Java
998     * implementing class, to confirm that it can still be returned successfully
999     * to PostgreSQL.
1000     * @param sx readable {@code SQLXML} object to proxy
1001     * @param how 1,2,4,5,6,7 determines what subclass of {@code Source} will be
1002     * returned by {@code getSource}.
1003     */
1004    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
1005              provides="proxiedXMLEcho")
1006    public static SQLXML proxiedXMLEcho(SQLXML sx, int how)
1007    throws SQLException
1008    {
1009        return new SQLXMLProxy(sx, how);
1010    }

1012    /**
1013     * Supply a sequence of bytes to be the exact (encoded) content of an XML
1014     * value, which will be returned; if the encoding is not UTF-8, the value
1015     * should begin with an XML Decl that names the encoding.
1016     *<p>
1017     * Constructs an {@code SQLXML} instance that will return the supplied
1018     * content as a {@code StreamSource} wrapping an {@code InputStream}, or via

1021    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
1022              provides="mockedXMLEchoB")
1023    public static SQLXML mockedXMLEcho(byte[] bytes)
1024    throws SQLException

1030     * Supply a sequence of characters to be the exact (Unicode) content of an

1032     * that names an encoding, the content will be assumed to contain only
1033     * characters representable in that encoding.
1034     *<p>
1035     * Constructs an {@code SQLXML} instance that will return the supplied
1036     * content as a {@code StreamSource} wrapping a {@code Reader}, or via
1037     * {@code getCharacterStream}, but fail if asked for any other form.
1038     */
1039    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
1040              provides="mockedXMLEchoC")
1041    public static SQLXML mockedXMLEcho(String chars)
1042    throws SQLException
1043    {

1051     * later.
1052     */
1053    @Function(schema="javatest", name="lowLevelXMLEcho",

1055    public static SQLXML lowLevelXMLEcho_(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx, int how,
1056        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)

1063     * Low-level XML echo where the Java parameter and return type are String.
1064     */
1065    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml", type="xml")
1066    public static String lowLevelXMLEcho(@SQLType("xml") String x)
1067    throws SQLException

1072    /**
1073     * Create some XML, pass it to a {@code SELECT ?} prepared statement,
1074     * retrieve it from the result set, and return it via the out-parameter
1075     * result set of this {@code RECORD}-returning function.
1076     */
1077    @Function(schema="javatest", type="RECORD")
1078    public static boolean xmlInStmtAndRS(ResultSet out) throws SQLException
1079    {
1080        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1081        SQLXML x = c.createSQLXML();
1082        x.setString("<a/>");
1083        PreparedStatement ps = c.prepareStatement("SELECT ?");
1084        ps.setObject(1, x, Types.SQLXML);
1085        ResultSet rs = ps.executeQuery();
1086        rs.next();
1087        if ( Types.SQLXML != rs.getMetaData().getColumnType(1) )
1088            logMessage("WARNING",
1089                "ResultSetMetaData.getColumnType() misreports SQLXML");
1090        x = rs.getSQLXML(1);
1091        ps.close();
1092        out.updateObject(1, x);
1093        return true;
1094    }
1095
1096    /**
1097     * Test serialization into the PostgreSQL server encoding by returning
1098     * a text node, optionally wrapped in an element, containing the supplied
1099     * stuff.
1100     *<p>
1101     * The stuff is supplied as a {@code bytea} and a named <em>encoding</em>,
1102     * so it is easy to supply stuff that isn't in the server encoding and see
1103     * what the serializer does with it.
1104     *<p>
1105     * As of this writing, if the <em>stuff</em>, decoded according to
1106     * <em>encoding</em>, contains characters that are not representable in the
1107     * server encoding, the serializers supplied in the JRE will:
1108     *<ul>
1109     *<li>SAX, DOM: replace the character with a numeric character reference if
1110     * the node is wrapped in an element, but not outside of an element; there,
1111     * PL/Java ensures an {@code UnmappableCharacterException} is thrown, as the
1112     * serializer would otherwise silently lose information by replacing the
1113     * character with a {@code ?}.
1114     *<li>StAX: replace the character with a numeric character reference whether
1115     * wrapped in an element or not (outside of an element, this officially
1116     * violates the letter of the XML spec, but does not lose information, and
1117     * is closer to the spirit of SQL/XML with its {@code XML(CONTENT)} type).
1118     *</ul>
1119     * @param stuff Content to be used in the text node
1120     * @param encoding Name of an encoding; stuff will be decoded to Unicode
1121     * according to this encoding, and then serialized into the server encoding,
1122     * where possible.
1123     * @param how Integer specifying which XML API to test, like every other how
1124     * in this class; here the only valid choices are 5 (SAX), 6 (StAX), or
1125     * 7 (DOM).
1126     * @param inElement True if the text node should be wrapped in an element.
1127     * @return The resulting XML content.
1128     */
1129    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
1130    public static SQLXML xmlTextNode(
1131        byte[] stuff, String encoding, int how, boolean inElement)
1132        throws Exception
1133    {
1134        if ( 5 > how || how > 7 )
1135            throw new SQLDataException(
1136                "how must be 5-7 for xmlTextNode", "22003");
1137
1138        String stuffString = new String(stuff, encoding);
1139        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1140        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
1141
1142        switch ( how )
1143        {
1144        case 5:
1145            SAXResult sxr = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
1146            sxr.getHandler().startDocument();
1147            if ( inElement )
1148                sxr.getHandler().startElement("", "sax", "sax",
1149                    new AttributesImpl());
1150            sxr.getHandler().characters(
1151                stuffString.toCharArray(), 0, stuffString.length());
1152            if ( inElement )
1153                sxr.getHandler().endElement("", "sax", "sax");
1154            sxr.getHandler().endDocument();
1155            break;
1156        case 6:
1157            StAXResult stxr = rx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
1158            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeStartDocument();
1159            if ( inElement )
1160                stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeStartElement("", "stax", "");
1161            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeCharacters(stuffString);
1162            if ( inElement )
1163                stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeEndElement();
1164            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeEndDocument();
1165            break;
1166        case 7:
1167            DOMResult dr = rx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
1168            /*
1169             * Why request features XML and Traversal?
1170             * If the only features requested are from the set
1171             * {Core, XML, LS} and maybe XPath, you get a brain-damaged
1172             * DOMImplementation that violates the org.w3c.dom.DOMImplementation
1173             * contract, as createDocument still tries to make a document
1174             * element even when passed null,null,null when, according to the
1175             * contract, it should not. To get the real implementation that
1176             * works, ask for some feature it supports outside of that core set.
1177             * I don't really need Traversal, but by asking for it, I get what
1178             * I do need.
1179             */
1180            Document d = DOMImplementationRegistry.newInstance()
1181                .getDOMImplementation("XML Traversal")
1182                .createDocument(null, null, null);
1183            DocumentFragment df = d.createDocumentFragment();
1184            ( inElement ? df.appendChild(d.createElement("dom")) : df )
1185                .appendChild(d.createTextNode(stuffString));
1186            dr.setNode(df);
1187            break;
1188        }
1189        return rx;
1190    }
1191
1192    /**
1193     * Create and leave some number of SQLXML objects unclosed, unused, and
1194     * unreferenced, as a test of reclamation.
1195     * @param howmany Number of SQLXML instances to create.
1196     * @param how If nonzero, the flavor of writing to request on the object
1197     * before abandoning it; if zero, it is left in its initial, writable state.
1198     */
1199    @Function(schema="javatest")
1200    public static void unclosedSQLXML(int howmany, int how) throws SQLException
1201    {
1202        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1203        while ( howmany --> 0 )
1204        {
1205            SQLXML sx = c.createSQLXML();
1206            if ( 0 < how )
1207                sxToResult(sx, how);
1208        }
1209    }
1210
1211
1212    /**
1213     * Return some instance of {@code Source} for reading an {@code SQLXML}
1214     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}.
1215     *<p>
1216     * Note that this method always returns a {@code Source}, even for cases
1217     * 1 and 2 (obtaining readable streams directly from the {@code SQLXML}
1218     * object; this method wraps them in {@code Source}), and case 3
1219     * ({@code getString}; this method creates a {@code StringReader} and
1220     * returns it wrapped in a {@code Source}.
1221     */
1222    private static Source sxToSource(SQLXML sx, int how) throws SQLException
1223    {
1224        switch ( how )
1225        {
1226            case  1: return new StreamSource(sx.getBinaryStream());
1227            case  2: return new StreamSource(sx.getCharacterStream());
1228            case  3: return new StreamSource(new StringReader(sx.getString()));
1229            case  4: return     sx.getSource(StreamSource.class);
1230            case  5: return     sx.getSource(SAXSource.class);
1231            case  6: return     sx.getSource(StAXSource.class);
1232            case  7: return     sx.getSource(DOMSource.class);
1233            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 1-7", "22003");
1234        }
1235    }
1236
1237    /**
1238     * Return some instance of {@code Result} for writing an {@code SQLXML}
1239     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}.
1240     *<p>
1241     * Note that this method always returns a {@code Result}, even for cases
1242     * 1 and 2 (obtaining writable streams directly from the {@code SQLXML}
1243     * object; this method wraps them in {@code Result}), and case 3
1244     * ({@code setString}; this method creates a {@code StringWriter} and
1245     * returns it wrapped in a {@code Result}.
1246     *<p>
1247     * In case 3, it will be necessary, after writing, to get the {@code String}
1248     * from the {@code StringWriter}, and call {@code setString} with it.
1249     */
1250    private static Result sxToResult(SQLXML sx, int how) throws SQLException
1251    {
1252        switch ( how )
1253        {
1254            case  1: return new StreamResult(sx.setBinaryStream());
1255            case  2: return new StreamResult(sx.setCharacterStream());
1256            case  3: return new StreamResult(new StringWriter());
1257            case  4: return     sx.setResult(StreamResult.class);
1258            case  5: return     sx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
1259            case  6: return     sx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
1260            case  7:
1261                DOMResult r = sx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
1262                allowFragment(r); // else it'll accept only DOCUMENT form
1263                return r;
1264            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 1-7", "22003");
1265        }
1266    }
1267
1268    /**
1269     * Return some instance of {@code Source} for reading an {@code SQLXML}
1270     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}, applying any adjustments
1271     * in {@code adjust}.
1272     *<p>
1273     * Allows {@code how} to be zero, meaning to let the implementation choose
1274     * what kind of {@code Source} to present. Otherwise identical to the other
1275     * {@code sxToSource}.
1276     */
1277    private static Source sxToSource(SQLXML sx, int how, ResultSet adjust)
1278    throws SQLException
1279    {
1280        Source s;
1281        switch ( how )
1282        {
1283            case  0: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.Source.class); break;
1284            case  1:
1285            case  2:
1286            case  3:
1287            case  4:
1288                return sxToSource(sx, how); // no adjustments on a StreamSource
1289            case  5: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.SAXSource.class); break;
1290            case  6: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.StAXSource.class); break;
1291            case  7: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.DOMSource.class); break;
1292            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 0-7", "22003");
1293        }
1294
1295        if ( s instanceof Adjusting.XML.Source )
1296            return applyAdjustments(adjust, (Adjusting.XML.Source<?>)s).get();
1297        return s;
1298    }
1299
1300    /**
1301     * Return some instance of {@code Result} for writing an {@code SQLXML}
1302     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how} applying any adjustments
1303     * in {@code adjust}.
1304     *<p>
1305     * Allows {@code how} to be zero, meaning to let the implementation choose
1306     * what kind of {@code Result} to present. Otherwise identical to the other
1307     * {@code sxToResult}.
1308     */
1309    private static Result sxToResult(SQLXML sx, int how, ResultSet adjust)
1310    throws SQLException
1311    {
1312        Result r;
1313        switch ( how )
1314        {
1315            case  1: // you might wish you could adjust a raw BinaryStream
1316            case  2: // or CharacterStream
1317            case  3: // or String, but you can't. Ask for a StreamResult.
1318            case  5: // SAXResult needs no adjustment
1319            case  6: // StAXResult needs no adjustment
1320            case  7: // DOMResult needs no adjustment
1321                return sxToResult(sx, how);
1322            case  4: r = sx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.StreamResult.class); break;
1323            case  0: r = sx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.Result.class); break;
1324            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 0-7", "22003");
1325        }
1326
1327        if ( r instanceof Adjusting.XML.Result )
1328            return applyAdjustments(adjust, (Adjusting.XML.Result<?>)r).get();
1329        return r;
1330    }
1331
1332    /**
1333     * Ensure the closing of whatever method was used to add content to
1334     * an {@code SQLXML} object.
1335     *<p>
1336     * Before a {@code SQLXML} object that has been written to can be used by
1337     * PostgreSQL (returned as a function result, plugged in as a prepared
1338     * statement parameter or into a {@code ResultSet}, etc.), the method used
1339     * for writing it must be "closed" to ensure the writing is complete.
1340     *<p>
1341     * If it is set with {@link SQLXML#setString setString}, nothing more is
1342     * needed; {@code setString} obviously sets the whole value at once. Any
1343     * {@code OutputStream} or {@code Writer} obtained from
1344     * {@link SQLXML#setBinaryStream setBinaryStream} or
1345     * {@link SQLXML#setCharacterStream setCharacterStream}, or from
1346     * {@link SQLXML#setResult setResult}{@code (StreamResult.class)}, has to be
1347     * explicitly closed (a {@link Transformer} does not close its
1348     * {@link Result} when the transformation is complete!).
1349     * Those are cases 1, 2, and 4 here.
1350     *<p>
1351     * Cases 5 ({@code SAXResult}) and 6 ({@code StAXResult}) need no special
1352     * attention; though the {@code Transformer} does not close them, the ones
1353     * returned by this {@code SQLXML} implementation are set up to close
1354     * themselves when the {@code endDocument} event is written.
1355     *<p>
1356     * Case 3 (test of {@code setString} is handled specially here. As this
1357     * class allows testing of all techniques for writing the {@code SQLXML}
1358     * object, and most of those involve a {@code Result}, case 3 is handled
1359     * by also constructing a {@code Result} over a {@link StringWriter} and
1360     * having the content written into that; this method then extracts the
1361     * content from the {@code StringWriter} and passes it to {@code setString}.
1362     * For cases 1 and 2, likewise, the stream obtained with
1363     * {@code getBinaryStream} or {@code getCharacterStream} has been wrapped in
1364     * a {@code Result} for generality in this example.
1365     *<p>
1366     * A typical application will not need the generality seen here; it
1367     * will usually know which technique it is using to write the {@code SQLXML}
1368     * object, and only needs to know how to close that if it needs closing.
1369     * @param r The {@code Result} onto which writing was done.
1370     * @param sx The {@code SQLXML} object being written.
1371     * @param how The integer used in this example class to select which method
1372     * of writing the {@code SQLXML} object was to be tested.
1373     * @return The {@code SQLXML} object {@code sx}, because why not?
1374     */
1375    public static SQLXML ensureClosed(Result r, SQLXML sx, int how)
1376    throws SQLException
1377    {
1378        switch ( how )
1379        {
1380        case 1:
1381        case 2:
1382        case 4:
1383            StreamResult sr = (StreamResult)r;
1384            OutputStream os = sr.getOutputStream();
1385            Writer w = sr.getWriter();
1386            try
1387            {
1388                if ( null != os )
1389                    os.close();
1390                if ( null != w )
1391                    w.close();
1392            }
1393            catch ( IOException ioe )
1394            {
1395                throw new SQLException(
1396                    "Failure closing SQLXML result", "XX000");
1397            }
1398            break;
1399        case 3:
1400            StringWriter sw = (StringWriter)((StreamResult)r).getWriter();
1401            String s = sw.toString();
1402            sx.setString(s);
1403            break;
1404        }
1405        return sx;
1406    }
1407
1408    /**
1409     * Configure a {@code DOMResult} to accept {@code CONTENT} (a/k/a
1410     * document fragment), not only the more restrictive {@code DOCUMENT}.
1411     *<p>
1412     * The other forms of {@code Result} that can be requested will happily
1413     * accept {@code XML(CONTENT)} and not just {@code XML(DOCUMENT)}.
1414     * The {@code DOMResult} is pickier, however: if you first call
1415     * {@link DOMResult#setNode setNode} with a {@code DocumentFragment}, it
1416     * will accept either form, but if you leave the node unset when passing the
1417     * {@code DOMResult} to a transformer, the transformer will default to
1418     * putting a {@code Document} node there, and then it will not accept a
1419     * fragment.
1420     *<p>
1421     * If you need to handle fragments, this method illustrates how to pre-load
1422     * the {@code DOMResult} with an empty {@code DocumentFragment}. Note that
1423     * if you use some XML processing package that supplies its own classes
1424     * implementing DOM nodes, you may need to use a {@code DocumentFragment}
1425     * instance obtained from that package.
1426     */
1427    public static void allowFragment(DOMResult r) throws SQLException
1428    {
1429        try
1430        {
1431            r.setNode(DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance()
1432                .newDocumentBuilder().newDocument()
1433                    .createDocumentFragment());
1434        }
1435        catch ( ParserConfigurationException pce )
1436        {
1437            throw new SQLException("Failed initializing DOMResult", pce);
1438        }
1439    }
1440
1441    private static void shovelBytes(InputStream is, OutputStream os)
1442    throws IOException
1443    {
1444        byte[] b = new byte[8192];
1445        int got;
1446        while ( -1 != (got = is.read(b)) )
1447            os.write(b, 0, got);
1448        is.close();
1449        os.close();
1450    }
1451
1452    private static void shovelChars(Reader r, Writer w)
1453    throws IOException
1454    {
1455        char[] b = new char[8192];
1456        int got;
1457        while ( -1 != (got = r.read(b)) )
1458            w.write(b, 0, got);
1459        r.close();
1460        w.close();
1461    }
1462
1463    /**
1464     * Test the MappedUDT (in one direction anyway).
1465     *<p>
1466     * Creates a {@code PassXML} object, the Java class that maps the
1467     * {@code javatest.onexml} composite type, which has one member, of XML
1468     * type. Stores a {@code SQLXML} value in that field of the {@code PassXML}
1469     * object, and passes that to an SQL query that expects and returns
1470     * {@code javatest.onexml}. Retrieves the XML from the value field of the
1471     * {@code PassXML} object created to map the result of the query.
1472     * @return The original XML value, if all goes well.
1473     */
1474    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
1475    public static SQLXML xmlFromComposite() throws SQLException
1476    {
1477        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1478        PreparedStatement ps =
1479            c.prepareStatement("SELECT CAST(? AS javatest.onexml)");
1480        SQLXML x = c.createSQLXML();
1481        x.setString("<a/>");
1482        PassXML obj = new PassXML();
1483        obj.m_value = x;
1484        obj.m_typeName = "javatest.onexml";
1485        ps.setObject(1, obj);
1486        ResultSet r = ps.executeQuery();
1487        r.next();
1488        obj = (PassXML)r.getObject(1);
1489        ps.close();
1490        return obj.m_value;
1491    }
1492
1493    /*
1494     * Required to serve as a MappedUDT:
1495     */
1496    /**
1497     * No-arg constructor required of objects that will implement
1498     * {@link SQLData}.
1499     */
1500    public PassXML() { }
1501
1502    private String m_typeName;
1503    private SQLXML m_value;
1504
1505    @Override
1506    public String getSQLTypeName() { return m_typeName; }
1507
1508    @Override
1509    public void readSQL(SQLInput stream, String typeName) throws SQLException
1510    {
1511        m_typeName = typeName;
1512        m_value = (SQLXML) stream.readObject();
1513    }
1514
1515    @Override
1516    public void writeSQL(SQLOutput stream) throws SQLException
1517    {
1518        stream.writeSQLXML(m_value);
1519    }

1521    /**
1522     * Class that will proxy methods to another {@code SQLXML} class.
1523     *<p>
1524     * Used for testing the PL/Java can accept input for PostgreSQL from an
1525     * {@code SQLXML} object not of its own implementation (for example, one
1526     * obtained from a different JDBC driver from some other database).
1527     *<p>
1528     * Only the {@code getSource} method is specially treated, to allow
1529     * exercising the various flavors of source.
1530     */
1531    public static class SQLXMLProxy implements SQLXML
1532    {
1533        private SQLXML m_sx;
1534        private int m_how;
1535
1536        public SQLXMLProxy(SQLXML sx, int how)
1537        {
1538            if ( null == sx )
1539                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLProxy target");
1540            if ( 1 > how  ||  how > 7  ||  how == 3 )
1541                throw new IllegalArgumentException(
1542                    "\"how\" must be 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, or 7");
1543            m_sx = sx;
1544            m_how = how;
1545        }
1546
1547        @Override
1548        public void free() throws SQLException { m_sx.free(); }
1549
1550        @Override
1551        public InputStream getBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1552        {
1553            return m_sx.getBinaryStream();
1554        }
1555
1556        @Override
1557        public OutputStream setBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1558        {
1559            return m_sx.setBinaryStream();
1560        }
1561
1562        @Override
1563        public Reader getCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1564        {
1565            return m_sx.getCharacterStream();
1566        }
1567
1568        @Override
1569        public Writer setCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1570        {
1571            return m_sx.setCharacterStream();
1572        }
1573
1574        @Override
1575        public String getString() throws SQLException
1576        {
1577            return m_sx.getString();
1578        }
1579
1580        @Override
1581        public void setString(String value) throws SQLException
1582        {
1583            m_sx.setString(value);
1584        }
1585
1586        @Override
1587        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // all the fun's when sourceClass is null
1588        public <T extends Source> T getSource(Class<T> sourceClass)
1589        throws SQLException
1590        {
1591            if ( null == sourceClass )
1592            {
1593                switch ( m_how )
1594                {
1595                case 1:
1596                    return (T)new StreamSource(m_sx.getBinaryStream());
1597                case 2:
1598                    return (T)new StreamSource(m_sx.getCharacterStream());
1599                case 4:
1600                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)StreamSource.class;
1601                    break;
1602                case 5:
1603                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)SAXSource.class;
1604                    break;
1605                case 6:
1606                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)StAXSource.class;
1607                    break;
1608                case 7:
1609                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)DOMSource.class;
1610                    break;
1611                }
1612            }
1613            return m_sx.getSource(sourceClass);
1614        }
1615
1616        @Override
1617        public <T extends Result> T setResult(Class<T> resultClass)
1618        throws SQLException
1619        {
1620            return m_sx.setResult(resultClass);
1621        }
1622    }
1623
1624    /**
1625     * Class that will mock an {@code SQLXML} instance, returning only binary or
1626     * character stream data from a byte array or string supplied at
1627     * construction.
1628     */
1629    public static class SQLXMLMock implements SQLXML
1630    {
1631        private String m_chars;
1632        private byte[] m_bytes;
1633
1634        public SQLXMLMock(String content)
1635        {
1636            if ( null == content )
1637                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLMock content");
1638            m_chars = content;
1639        }
1640
1641        public SQLXMLMock(byte[] content)
1642        {
1643            if ( null == content )
1644                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLMock content");
1645            m_bytes = content;
1646        }
1647
1648        @Override
1649        public void free() throws SQLException { }
1650
1651        @Override
1652        public InputStream getBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1653        {
1654            if ( null != m_bytes )
1655                return new ByteArrayInputStream(m_bytes);
1656            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1657                "SQLXMLMock.getBinaryStream");
1658        }
1659
1660        @Override
1661        public OutputStream setBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1662        {
1663            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1664                "SQLXMLMock.setBinaryStream");
1665        }
1666
1667        @Override
1668        public Reader getCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1669        {
1670            if ( null != m_chars )
1671                return new StringReader(m_chars);
1672            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1673                "SQLXMLMock.getCharacterStream");
1674        }
1675
1676        @Override
1677        public Writer setCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1678        {
1679            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1680                "SQLXMLMock.setCharacterStream");
1681        }
1682
1683        @Override
1684        public String getString() throws SQLException
1685        {
1686            if ( null != m_chars )
1687                return m_chars;
1688            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1689                "SQLXMLMock.getString");
1690        }
1691
1692        @Override
1693        public void setString(String value) throws SQLException
1694        {
1695            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1696                "SQLXMLMock.setString");
1697        }
1698
1699        @Override
1700        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // sourceClass==StreamSource is verified
1701        public <T extends Source> T getSource(Class<T> sourceClass)
1702        throws SQLException
1703        {
1704            if ( null != sourceClass && StreamSource.class != sourceClass )
1705                throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1706                    "SQLXMLMock.getSource(" + sourceClass.getName() + ")");
1707            if ( null != m_chars )
1708                return (T) new StreamSource(new StringReader(m_chars));
1709            return (T) new StreamSource(new ByteArrayInputStream(m_bytes));
1710        }
1711
1712        @Override
1713        public <T extends Result> T setResult(Class<T> resultClass)
1714        throws SQLException
1715        {
1716            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1717                "SQLXMLMock.setResult");
1718        }
1719    }
1720}
